{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3542168,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-27T02:59:30.902Z","cooked":"

I’m looking for a collection of tips and tricks and conventional wisdom to make sysId routine give better data.

Here are mine to start, but I never seems to have all of the pieces perfect. Also please let me know if any of these items seem off or if anyone has better tricks.

  1. CTRE: Use Signal logger.
  2. CTRE: Set Base frequency using the PhoenixSysId example on github
  3. Spark Max: Set the Spark Max Encoder to a depth of 2 and a measurement period of 16
  4. Spark Flex: I’m doing the same thing with depth and measurement period, but I don’t know if there are better combinations of numbers for depth and period
  5. Something I do but need some convincing that is is correct. Use a small project for collection instead of making SysIdRoutine’s part of the project. A bit clunky, but I think I get better results when I ignore all of the existing items on the robot and internal telemetry tracking.
  6. run routines with buttons on a controller and not the dashboard. The lag can be a problem.

Some things I need help with

  1. tuning position with the position error and velocity error values.
  2. interpreting the measurement delays (is a negative value a red flag for a bad run
  3. kd. I always get ridiculous high numbers that cause jitter. I either remove it or use a smaller (best guess) value.
  4. Can I use advantage scope to trim out suspect data points for a better result.

narmstro:

kd. I always get ridiculous high numbers that cause jitter. I either remove it or use a smaller (best guess) value

You are experiencing latency. Latency will severely restrict the maximum kD you can reasonably run and usually destabilizes the system. If you can identify this maximum kD, you can use the sysID parameters to design for a damping ratio of 1.0 while letting kP be whatever it ends up being. Noise amplification may also be a problem, but I’d expect it to come from latency first in absence of other information.

narmstro:

tuning position with the position error and velocity error values

This is easy, instead of using the kD normally, feed in a reference velocity and let the derivative control action be kD*reference velocity

narmstro:

Here are mine to start, but I never seems to have all of the pieces perfect. Also please let me know if any of these items seem off or if anyone has better tricks.

Have you considered sysID methods that are not WPIlibs sysID? There are many ways to identify the dynamics of the system, and some are more appropriate in some situations than others. I’ve had a lot of luck using frequency-domain methods (both white noise and stepped sine), and they come with the advantage of also generating a phase plot, which allows you to characterize latency and they also work better high-bandwidth systems than time-domain methods do.

Alex_Y:

You are experiencing latency. Latency will severely restrict the maximum kD you can reasonably run and usually destabilizes the system. If you can identify this maximum kD, you can use the sysID parameters to design for a damping ratio of 1.0 while letting kP be whatever it ends up being. Noise amplification may also be a problem, but I’d expect it to come from latency first in absence of other information.

So could I lower the measurement period to improve this.

It will help minimize errors caused by discretization and breaking algebraic loops, but will not remove errors caused by pure latency, like from the CAN bus.

Alex_Y:

Have you considered sysID methods that are not WPIlibs sysID? There are many ways to identify the dynamics of the system, and some are more appropriate in some situations than others.

Do you have any in mind?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-28T03:29:10.939Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":493426,"topic_slug":"ways-to-improve-my-sysid-results","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-improve-my-sysid-results/493426/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3543188,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-28T03:52:31.021Z","cooked":"

I’ve used both white noise and stepped sines to characterize various systems and the both work and are extremely common outside of FRC. White noise is fast and dirty, but it is effective at characterizing high-bandwidth systems and pure time delay as long as you are aware of the quirks of the DFT, while stepped sines is a lot more accurate, but is a slower test to run and can’t characterize high-bandwidth systems easily. Unlike time domain methods, frequency domain methods can identify systems with limited travel or that just move so fast that a time-domain method can only gather a few milliseconds of data, while frequency-domain methods let you gather as much data as you want.
